Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Building Strong and Tough Multiphase Ceramics via Interface Tailoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Strength and toughness are two important properties of structural materials, but they are often times mutually exclusive, especially in ceramic materials. Materials with high strength can carry higher loads before they fail, and materials with high toughness can deform to a greater extent without breaking. This EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports research focused on the formation of new types of ceramic materials by blending two different phases to simultaneously achieve high strength and high toughness. It is hypothesized that structural changes at the microscopic scale will occur across the interfaces of these phases when the materials deform, which will result in increased overall toughness in an already high strength material system. Ceramic materials with high toughness have potential use for the development of super-efficient power plants, high temperature gas sensors, thermal protection systems for space vehicles and many other engineering applications. As such, results from this will benefit the U.S. economy and society. In addition, this award will support enhancement of teaching, training and learning through mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students.

The objective of this research is to explore the formation of new types of Zirconium (Zr) based multiphase ceramic materials by selectively choosing phases with thermodynamically compatible crystal structures but different lattice constants to form energy dissipating microstructures. Three types of multiphase ceramics will be manufactured, namely ZrC-ZrB2 nanocomposites, ZrC-ZrB2 multilayer laminates and ZrB2-HfB2 solid solutions. Both experimental characterization and atomistic computations will be conducted to determine relative densities, grain sizes, and phases present in the fabricated solid solutions, nanocomposites, and laminates. The strength, fracture toughness, microhardness, and elastic properties of ceramics, nanocomposites, and laminates will be measured experimentally and calculated computationally. Following mechanical testing, fracture surfaces of the specimens will be examined to identify the failure origins. Atomistic computations will be performed to reveal atomic scale toughening mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• Through collaboration between Missouri Science and Technology (MS&T) and the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), the current project involved manufacturing, experimental characterization and molecular level simulations of polycrystalline ZrB2 and ZrC-ZrB2 nanocomposites.These materials have potential structural applications in hypersonic aerospace vehicle or rocket propulsion system.
  • Reactive hot-pressing (RHP) method has been used for producing high purity ZrB2 and its nanocomposites. Molecular level computations have been performed to understand how the materials evolve when mechanical forces are applied to them. A novel approach has been followed to evaluate tensile and shear properties of the grain boundary material.
  • The new understanding that has been generated from this study is that mechanical properties of both ZrB2 and ZrC-ZrB2 nanocomposite depend on their grain boundary properties. It has been observed that the structural failure of both ZrB2 and ZrC-ZrB2 occurs at the grain boundary via grain boundary sliding and void creation. It means when mechanical force is applied to either pure ZrB2 or ZrC-ZrB2 nanocomposite, the grain boundaries of both materials slide nearly the same way.
  • One postdoctoral research associate, one PhD student and two undergraduate students have been trained through this research program. One of the undergraduate students was female. The postdoctoral associate has learned how to manufacture and experimentally characterize the materials. The PhD student and the undergraduate students have been trained on analytical and computational modeling. These individuals could potentially have career related to structural engineering and high temperature ceramics. 
  • The following products have been generated out of this study
  • Md. Riaz Kayser, Sheikh Fahad Ferdous, Ashfaq Adnan, Computational Design of Zirconium (Zr) Based Multiphase Ceramic Materials for Improved Strength and Toughness Properties - presented at the MS&T 16, Salt Lake city, UT, Oct 23-27, 2016
  • Neuman EW, Fahrenholtz WG, Hilmas GE. Factorial Design to Minimize Residual Oxygen in Reaction Hot-pressed Zirconium Diboride, accepted for publication in the International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology, March 12, 2017. 
  • ?Md. Riaz Kayser, Ashfaq Adnan, (2017). Grain boundary driven mechanical properties of ZrB2 and ZrC-ZrB2 nanocomposites: A molecular simulation study.  Under Review May 2017
